etymology.description: 貝(貝) (bèi, 'shell/money') + 弗(弗) (fú, 'not') = related to payments and expenses -> fee
etymology.interpretation: 費(費) (fèi) represents matters related to expenses by combining 貝(貝) (bèi, 'shell/money'), which symbolizes wealth or money, with 弗(弗) (fú, 'not'), serving as the phonetic component. Historically, shells were used as currency, linking the character to financial transactions.
etymology.simplification: 費(費)→费(費): 貝(貝) (bèi, 'shell/money') was simplified by removing the inner strokes for a more streamlined form.

examples.chinese: 我花了很多钱(我花了很多錢)，支付学费(支付學費)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ huā le hěnduō qián, zhīfù xuéfèi.
examples.english: I spent a lot of money to pay tuition fees.

examples.chinese: 公司为新项目支出了高额费用(公司為新項目支出了高額費用)。
examples.pinyin: Gōngsī wèi xīn xiàngmù zhīchū le gāo’é fèiyòng.
examples.english: The company incurred high expenses for the new project.
